info.title: Running &openscap; compliance scans for &productname;

abstract.para: This guide explains how to use &openscap; to run compliance scans on Enterprise Linux systems registered with &productname; &productnumber;.

info.meta: How to use &openscap; to run compliance scans on systems registered with &productname; &productnumber;.

important.title: End of general support for &productname; &productnumber;
important.para: &productname; &productnumber; has reached the end of general support and is now in LTSS (Long Term Service Support).

If you have a &productname; subscription but do not have an LTSS subscription, you can continue to use your systems. However, registering new &rhla; &productnumber; or CentOS Linux &productnumber; systems with the general subscription is no longer supported.

Additionally, the optional &ha; extension is no longer supported with &productname; &productnumber; LTSS. You must remove this product from your system before you can register with an LTSS subscription.

section.title: Introduction
section.para: &productname; is a technology and support solution for mixed Linux environments. With a &productname; subscription, you can register and update &rhel; and CentOS Linux.
&productname; uses its own branding and paths different from &rhla; and CentOS Linux. This means it also uses different profiles for running compliance scans with &openscap;.

SCAP (Security Content Automation Protocol) is a framework of specifications that support automated configuration, vulnerability scanning, and policy compliance evaluation of systems deployed in an organization. It also standardizes how vulnerabilities and security configurations are communicated both to machines and humans.
&openscap; is a collection of open source tools that implement the SCAP framework for Linux.
&productname; provides the following components in its software update repositories:

listitem.para: The &openscap; scanner and utilities.

The &ssg;, a collection of security guidance and baselines from
to apply against systems for compliance.
SCAP Workbench, a utility with a graphical user interface for SCAP content tailoring, editing, and validation.

section.title: Requirements
section.para: Before running compliance scans, make sure your system meets the following requirements:

listitem.para: You can log in to the target system as either the &rootuser; user or a user with sudo privileges. Without &rootuser; access, some tests in the compliance scan might not run correctly.
The target system is registered with &productname; as described in one of the following guides:
The most recent versions of the following packages are installed:

important.title: Supported scap-security-guide version
important.para: &rhla; 7 and its clones are no longer supported by the upstream ComplianceAsCode project. Therefore, the most recent version of scap-security-guide available from the &productname; LTSS &productnumber; repository is scap-security-guide-0.1.73-1.el7_9.

listitem.para: Installing these packages might also install additional dependencies.
The installed packages are provided by &suse;. You can check the vendor with the rpm -qi command. For example:
listitem.screen: &prompt.root;rpm -qi openscap-scanner | grep -i vendor Vendor : SUSE LLC <https://www.suse.com/>
listitem.para: You can also check the distribution name. For example:

If the vendor or distribution is different from the output shown above, reinstall the packages from the &productname; LTSS &productnumber; repository, and make sure no other repository overrides &productname;.

tip.title: SCAP Workbench
tip.para: The optional package scap-workbench is also available, but is not required to run scans locally from the command line.

As a security best practice, avoid installing an application software such as SCAP Workbench on the target system. Instead, install SCAP Workbench on a client machine and scan the target system remotely.

section.title: Including remote resources in an &openscap; compliance scan
section.para: &productname; provides external OVAL-formatted content that you can use during scans. This content is downloaded from and includes information such as recently addressed security vulnerabilities. To include remote content in a compliance scan, use one of the following procedures, depending on your security requirements:

listitem.para: Directly download the remote content during the compliance scan, as described in .
Download the remote content and save it as a local file to use in the compliance scan, as described in .

important.para: Scans using remote resources take more time to complete, and the generated reports are much larger than usual.

section.title: Reviewing the &openscap; evaluation report
section.para: The HTML-formatted &openscap; report contains information collected from the target system and evaluated against the rules set by the selected compliance profile. The examples below show the main features of the report.

listitem.para: The header of the report shows information about the chosen compliance profile.

figure.title: Header of a typical HTML-formatted report generated by OpenSCAP

textobject.phrase: The header of a typical HTML-formatted report generated by OpenSCAP. This example report is titled "Guide to the Secure Configuration of SUSE Liberty Linux 7" and uses the profile "CIS Benchmark for Level 2 - Server".

listitem.para: The Compliance and Scoring section shows a summary of the compliance scan's results, including the number of passed and failed rules, as well as the severity of the failures.

figure.title: Summary of results in a typical HTML-formatted report generated by OpenSCAP

textobject.phrase: The Compliance and Scoring section shows a green and red color-coded bar indicating the number of passed and failed rules. It also shows a color-coded bar indicating the severity of the failed rules, in this case mostly blue (low) and yellow (medium). There is also a percentage score of passed rules. This example shows 68.72%.

listitem.para: The Rule Overview section shows a list of rules included with the compliance profile, along with the severity and test result of each rule. This section is interactive. You can check and uncheck filter options, group rules by different criteria, search the list with a search bar, and click the rule names to see more details.

figure.title: List of rules in a typical HTML-formatted report generated by OpenSCAP

textobject.phrase: The Rule Overview section shows the full list of rules along with their severity and test results. Above the list is a group of check boxes for filtering the rule list, a search bar to search the list, and a drop-down list of different ways to group the rules in the list.

listitem.para: Clicking the name of a rule opens a window showing detailed information about that rule. Depending on the rule, the detail window might also include multiple remediation options. Click (show) to expand each remediation option.

textobject.phrase: This example shows details about the rule Ensure /home Located On Separate Partition, including the result, the time the test ran, the severity of the rule, clickable references, a description of the rule, and a rationale for the rule. The bottom of the window has an expandable Remediation script and Remediation Anaconda snippet.

section.para: You can also expand the details for every rule by clicking Show all result details at the bottom of the report.
